sub_topic: Using the mean value theorem to solve problems
message_1: A car is traveling down a straight road. The car starts at rest at time t=0 and travels a distance of 300 meters in the first 10 seconds. Use the Mean Value Theorem to find the average velocity of the car over the interval [0, 10].
message_2:
To find the average velocity of the car over the interval [0, 10], we can use the Mean Value Theorem. The Mean Value Theorem states that if a function is continuous on the closed interval [a, b] and differentiable on the open interval (a, b), then there exists a number c in the interval (a, b) such that the derivative of the function at c is equal to the average rate of change of the function over the interval [a, b].

In this case, the function represents the position of the car, and we want to find the average velocity over the interval [0, 10]. The average velocity is the total distance traveled divided by the time taken. 

Average velocity = (Final position - Initial position) / (Final time - Initial time)

Since the car starts at rest and travels 300 meters in the first 10 seconds, the initial position is 0 meters, and the final position is 300 meters. The initial time is 0 seconds, and the final time is 10 seconds.

Average velocity = (300 - 0) / (10 - 0)
Average velocity = 300 / 10
Average velocity = 30 m/s

So, the average velocity of the car over the interval [0, 10] is 30 meters per second.
